summary: This document is a regulatory text from the Code of Federal Regulations (5 C.F.R. ยง 2635.705) titled 'Use of official time.' It outlines ethical standards for federal employees regarding the proper use of work hours and prohibits superiors from coercing subordinates to perform personal tasks on official time. It is not a case-specific document and contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or events.
keyFacts: The document is a standard federal regulation (5 C.F.R. ยง 2635.705) concerning the ethical use of official time by government employees.
It provides examples of proper and improper uses of official time, such as union activities or personal tasks.
It prohibits employees from encouraging, directing, coercing, or requesting subordinates to use official time for non-official duties.
The document is current through November 14, 2022, and is published by Thomson Reuters/Westlaw.
This file appears to be part of a larger document set but contains no substantive information related to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or the associated investigations.
